Alas!  the dear minutes are gone,</br>And all that the heart can improve,</br>And winter, stern winter, comes on,</br>And past are the seasons of love.
No longer by fair Orwell's stream,</br>Shall I carelessly wander along,</br>To indulge a poetical dream,</br>Or to listen to Philomel's song.
Dull and desolate now is the scene</br>Where the nymphs and the villagers met,</br>To enliven the sports of the Green,</br>With the pipe and the sweet clarinet.
The streams, and the riv'lets and fountains,</br>Their musical murmurs have lost;</br>And the lawns, and the valleys, and mountains</br>Are cover'd all over with frost.
The rose, nor the lilly, shall bloom,</br>No flowers shall sweeten the vale;</br>Nor the vi'let her fragrant perfume</br>Shall lend to the soft-breathing gale.
The blackbird no more from the thorn</br>Shall warble his wind notes at even;</br>Nor the lark, at the twilight of morn,</br>Shall send up her matins to heaven.
Ah!  why does my Phillis withold</br>The music that dwells on her tongue?</br>Though her shepherd neglects oft his fold</br>When he listens to Phillida's song.
When he thinks of his Phillida's form,</br>How her presence enliven'd the plain;</br>He sighs at the wintery storm,</br>And wishes for summer again.
Still memory haunts the dear grove,</br>Where in raptures we've wasted the day,</br>Or enjoy'd the sweet converse of love,</br>As we've wander'd at evening grey.
But if Phillis forsakes her fond swain,</br>Well may winter o'er-shadow the year;</br>And well may the grove and the plain</br>To him like a desart appear.</br>
